content:
How can this be validated?
There is no proper statement. One can only understand what to do looking at the testcases.
The task is trivial and has no interest.
The stub does not parse the input (which seems to be intentional considering the discussions below, but that's obviously terrible design).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is Good And it seems diffrent from the puzzles i have solved before so feel great to contribute...

This is a very badly written CoC.
Goal: Add the numbers at each position in two lists if they have equal length.

Stub generator works for all languages but leaves a huge burden on those where you have to declare variables and array sizes so I'm definitely against not specifying those parameters.

Nevertheless, Input description should be something like: A space separated list of integers. Accordingly Output should be: A space separated list where every element is the sum of the elements at that position in the input list. Print Invalid of the input lists have different length. Make Invalid into blue background as it is a constant.

Constraints:
Lists are not empty. All integers and their sums are int he range −32768 to 32767.

Also I wouldn't find a CoC fun when you have to add numbers together explicitly but seemingly others do.

Can you also please change the title to Add integers of two lists.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good idea

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good idea.
Perfect. Liked it.
I strongly recommend to change the validator tests. At the moment, one can hard-code the results and get a 100% score...

You specify that the range is "from −32,768 to 32,767".
Does that mean the solution will need to deal with commas for n >=1000?
If not, I suggest changing the range to "from −32768 to 32767"

>If length of the strings is not equal print Invalid
According to this rule, Test 2, which has inputs "1 5 6 7" [string length 7] and "-3 2 0 1" [string length 8] should print Invalid

Suggestion: change rule to "the number of integers respesented by the strings" instead of "length of the strings"

The range of integers in the two strings have not been specified.
What if there is carry-over?

its nice clash of medium level.i upvoted but your stub looks wrong
read s1:string(7)
read s2:string(7)
i think it should be string(7) instead of string(3)
as maximum length of string that you are giving as input is 7
I like it, good for shortest and reverse.
yes, only for shortest and reverse. No fastest marked ;)

You're right in both cases.
It's corrected now.
Thank you.
Could you write 1-2 validators?

Title partly changed.
These are strings, not lists (arrays).
Length > 0 means the same as "lists are not empty".
Which parameters are not specified? Feel free to change anything if you are convinced it makes clash better.

Based on your response you consider everything a string then. Which makes this CoC not match the 900 other were parameters are specified correctly. The aim of any kind of puzzle and CoC is not that the solver have to guess random bits about the task based on and example.

Length > 0 means the same as "lists are not empty". <- In what world is this correct. Line 1 is " ". It is clearly not empty and still does not contain anything. If you say they are strings and not list with a clear separator the whole thing becomes a game of guessing whether your solution will fail some badly written test-validator pair or not.

There are a bag of languages where you have to specify the size of an array before use. So for those languages this CoC is just a guessing game whether you set the initial size correctly or will fail some random validator. And that is an unfair disadvantage for anyone wanting to choose the language freely.
I changed the validators and added a fifth test with larger and negative values. Alright.
Why not ? It could be fun in fastest too
Reversed is fastest any -way. I hate these fastest clashes with long description. Plus, this way there is higher probability you will get shortest.
